question_details.title: Will the FDA approve a seasonal influenza vaccine for the 2025-2026 flu season before October 1, 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-03-04 21:38:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/35582). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

On February 26, 2025, the FDA unexpectedly canceled its Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee (VRBPAC) meeting that was scheduled for March 2025. This meeting is typically held annually to select the influenza virus strains to be included in the upcoming season's flu vaccines for the United States.

The FDA has maintained an uninterrupted annual approval process for seasonal influenza vaccines since 1973. Each year, the FDA follows a consistent timeline for approving updated flu vaccine formulations based on recommendations about which influenza strains are likely to circulate during the upcoming flu season. The strain selection process typically occurs in spring to give vaccine manufacturers sufficient time to produce shots for fall distribution.

The cancellation coincides with other significant changes in U.S. public health policy:

* In January 2025, President Donald Trump issued an executive order to begin withdrawing the U.S. from the World Health Organization (WHO)
* Federal health officials were subsequently ordered to stop communicating with the WHO
* A CDC vaccine advisory committee meeting was also recently postponed

question_details.fine_print:
For resolution purposes, a "seasonal influenza vaccine" refers to any vaccine formulation specifically developed for the 2025-2026 influenza season. This excludes previously approved vaccines that might be used off-label or as substitutes in the absence of a newly formulated vaccine.

If the FDA approves a multi-year influenza vaccine that explicitly covers the 2025-2026 season, this will count as a **YES** resolution.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Florida’s School Vaccine Requirement Change Will Not Take Effect Until December**
Florida’s Department of Health announced that a modification to school vaccination requirements will not take effect until at least 90 days after its introduction on September 3 2025, effectively delaying implementation until December. The change will reduce mandatory vaccines to varicella, hepatitis B, influenza Hib, and pneumococcal diseases, while keeping polio, measles, diphtheria, pertussis, mumps, and tetanus. The decision places responsibility on parents, as stated by state health secretary Joseph Ladapo: 'Si quieren, Dios los bendiga, pueden poner todas las que deseen. Y si no, los padres deben tener la capacidad y el poder de decidir qué entra en el cuerpo de sus hijos. Es así de simple'. The move follows a rise in vaccine‑preventable diseases: measles has reached its worst U.S. outbreak in over 30 years with more than 1,400 confirmed cases and three deaths, mainly in Texas; pertussis has caused the deaths of at least two babies in Louisiana and a five‑year‑old in Washington, with more than 19,000 reported cases as of August 23, up nearly 2,000 from the same date last year, according to CDC preliminary data. The World Health Organization reports that vaccines have saved at least 154 million lives worldwide in the past 50 years. Florida currently allows religious exemptions. The state legislature will not reconvene until January 2026, with committees meeting in October, meaning the current vaccination schedule will remain in force for the rest of the year.

Source:[CiberCuba](https://www.cibercuba.com/noticias/2025-09-15-u1-e135253-s27061-nid310966-cambio-norma-vacunas-escolares-florida-entrara-vigor)

**Despite Policy Confusion, Vaccines for Flu, COVID Still Strongly Recommended**
Michigan Medicine experts explain that flu, RSV, and COVID vaccines remain essential for preventing severe disease and death. Pamela Rockwell, D.O., notes that immunization rates are falling, citing a recent measles outbreak and that 14 Michigan children died of the flu last year, most unvaccinated. Adam Lauring, M.D., Ph.D., confirms that the science of vaccine benefit hasn't changed. He states the 2025‑2026 flu vaccine is updated and should be available soon; for most people it can be taken anytime, but if not high‑risk, October is acceptable. Lauring also describes FluMist, an inhaled live‑attenuated vaccine approved for home use in ages 2‑49, noting it can cause mild sniffles but does not give flu. RSV vaccine recommendations target people over 75, those 50‑74 with chronic conditions, and pregnant women between 32‑36 weeks; a monoclonal antibody, nirsevimab, protects infants ≤8 months. CDC data for the 2024‑2025 RSV season show 190,000‑350,000 hospitalizations and 10,000‑23,000 deaths. Regarding COVID, Rockwell says the recommendation that people 6 months and older are eligible remains, but policy changes may limit access: the FDA ended emergency use for Pfizer in kids under 5, leaving Moderna as the only option; the FDA now recommends COVID vaccines only for those 65+ or at high risk, listing conditions such as heart disease, lung disease, cancer, obesity, chronic kidney disease, liver disease, diabetes, depression, disabilities, physical inactivity, pregnancy, etc. She warns that insurance coverage could be jeopardized and that many patients declined the vaccine when offered.

Source:[The Good Men Project](https://goodmenproject.com/featured-content/despite-policy-confusion-vaccines-for-flu-covid-still-strongly-recommended/)

**How RFK Jr. just made getting vaccinated a matter of what state you live in**
Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the U.S. Health and Human Services secretary, has reversed many vaccine policies, sparking a split across states. In June, he dismissed all 17 members of the CDC’s independent advisory panel on immunization and replaced them with vaccine skeptics, claiming the move was to 're‑establish public confidence in vaccine science.' He also cancelled $500 million in federal funding for mRNA vaccine research and removed former CDC director Susan Monarez in late August. The FDA narrowed approval of updated COVID‑19 shots for people under 65 to those with at least one underlying condition, excluding otherwise eligible individuals.

States have responded in divergent ways. The West Coast Health Alliance—Washington, Oregon, California, and Hawaii—announced it would issue its own vaccine guidance to counter the CDC’s "destruction." Florida, led by Surgeon General Joseph Ladapo and Governor Ron DeSantis, became the first state to abolish school vaccine mandates, with Ladapo declaring that 'every last one of them is wrong and drips with disdain and slavery.' In contrast, New Mexico, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, and Colorado allowed pharmacies to administer COVID‑19 vaccines without prescriptions. Massachusetts Gov. Maura Healey ordered insurers to cover all state‑recommended immunizations; New York Gov. Kathy Hochul signed an executive order protecting near‑universal access to COVID‑19 vaccines until October 5; Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz and New Jersey Dept. of Health expanded pharmacy access; Virginia Health Commissioner Karen Shelton cleared pharmacy administration for adults 65+ and certain 18‑64 medical conditions. Illinois remains undecided, expecting guidance by end of September. Former CDC chief of staff Kyle McGowan warned that without federal leadership, states would pursue "50 states doing 50 different things."
Original language: en
Publish date: September 13, 2025 01:03 PM
Source:[The Independent](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/covid-vaccine-2025-trump-rfk-where-b2820238.html)

**Butantan’s Race to Produce 80 Million Flu Vaccine Doses Before Next Winter**
The article explains how the Instituto Butantan in São Paulo is operating a "war‑like" effort to produce 80 million doses of the seasonal influenza vaccine before the upcoming winter. The vaccine relies on an inactivated virus that must be updated each year to match the circulating strain. According to Priscila Comone, manager of the Influenza Virus Banks (PBI), "Quando a Organização Mundial da Saúde [OMS] anuncia a necessidade de atualização do imunizante, precisamos trazer os novos vírus do exterior de maneira prioritária, uma vez que seu rápido recebimento é essencial para garantir que o produto seja fabricado a tempo e aplicado na população‑alvo antes da chegada do inverno, período crítico da doença." The update is traditionally announced on the last Friday of September; Butantan’s nine areas and 15 professionals coordinate the import of strains from the United States, United Kingdom, China, Japan and Australia. The vaccine contains three strains—two A subtypes (H1N1 and H3N2) and one B subtype that infects only humans. Historically, only one of these strains changes annually.

A critical logistical challenge is the supply of eggs, the medium in which the virus is amplified. More than 500 000 eggs are required each day for five months, and they must come from specially raised, pathogen‑free chickens. Two weeks before the WHO announcement, Butantan schedules two deliveries: 500 000 eggs from certified Brazilian farms and 1 700 eggs imported from the United States, classified as Specific Pathogen Free. These eggs are used to produce a 2 ml "seed bank" of the imported strain. If only one strain changes, the factory can continue producing the two unchanged monovalent vaccines while expediting the new strain’s import. The coordinated September operation allows the first batches to be ready in March–April of the following year, enabling the federal government to distribute the doses nationwide before the June winter onset.

Key metrics: 80 million doses planned; 500 000 eggs/day for five months; 1 700 imported eggs; three vaccine strains; production ready by March–April; distribution before June.

**Influenza: AIFA Approves 11 Vaccines; Ministry Sets Vaccination Campaigns for Early October**
The Italian Medicines Agency (AIFA) and the European Medicines Agency (EMA) have authorised 11 influenza vaccines for the 2025‑2026 season. The vaccines—Efluelda, Efluelda Tetra, Fluad, Fluarix, Fluarix Tetra, Flucelvax, Fluenz, Influvac S, Influvac S Tetra, Vaxigrip, and Vaxigrip Tetra—are selected based on the WHO‑recommended viral strains for the upcoming season. AIFA notes that not all authorised vaccines are automatically available on the market; each region must bid for the products it will supply for the free national vaccination campaigns. The Ministry of Health has announced that the vaccination campaigns will begin in early October, as stated in AIFA’s press note: 'Campagne vaccinali da inizio ottobre'. AIFA also emphasised the long‑standing safety record of influenza vaccines, adding: 'I vaccini antinfluenzali sono utilizzati da anni nelle campagne vaccinali ed hanno un profilo di sicurezza consolidato'. The agency monitors vaccine safety through the National Pharmacovigilance Network (RNF) and regional centres, collecting and analysing reports of suspected adverse reactions from healthcare professionals and citizens.

**Confusion, fear over healthcare**
Doctors, pharmacies and care providers are overwhelmed by patients worried they cannot receive the 2025‑26 COVID vaccination because state pharmacies will not administer shots without a prescription. One doctor recounted spending 30 minutes returning calls from anxious patients and said, 'Had I reviewed their histories and written vaccine prescriptions it would have taken all day. I would have had to reschedule 18 future appointments to make up that lost day.' The article blames Health and Human Secretary Robert Kennedy for an anti‑vaccination stance, noting that he fired the Advisory Panel on Immunization Practices, the body that approves immunization recommendations. Without that panel’s approval, most states will not allow COVID shots without a written prescription. It cites a September 17‑18 panel meeting that will now be staffed by Kennedy’s appointees, raising concerns about decision‑making.

The piece also highlights federal budget cuts: CDC funding has been cut by nearly half, leading to eroded confidence among health professionals; the National Institutes of Health has lost more than $2 billion in grants and 1,300 jobs, causing research and clinical trials to be canceled. It warns that a projected $1 billion cut to Medicaid from Trump’s “Big Beautiful Bill” will take effect in October 2026, and that North Carolina’s Department of Health and Human Services has recommended a $819 million Medicaid increase for the current budget year, but only $500 million was authorized. This shortfall forces a minimum 3 % reduction in payments to Medicaid providers and a 10 % cut for inpatient, residential, behavioral therapy and autism services.

The article predicts that over 600,000 Medicaid‑expanded enrollees could lose benefits, pushing more patients to emergency departments. It also raises the possibility that the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA) could be revised or repealed under the financial strain on hospitals, potentially leading to the closure of rural hospitals. Finally, it reports a new COVID strain, Stratus, surging in South Carolina and other southern states.

The tone is highly sensational, using loaded language and political framing to present a narrative of crisis and blame.

**AIFA Approves 11 Vaccines for the 2025‑2026 Influenza Season**
On September 9, 2025, AIFA and the European Medicines Agency (EMA) announced that 11 influenza vaccines have been authorized for the 2025‑2026 season. The authorization updates the viral strains in line with WHO recommendations. The vaccines, listed with their manufacturers and target groups, include: Efluelda and Efluelda Tetra (Sanofi Winthrop) for adults ≥ 60; Fluad (Seqirus) for adults ≥ 50; Fluarix and Fluarix Tetra (GlaxoSmithKline) for adults and children ≥ 6 months; Flucelvax (Seqirus) for adults and children ≥ 6 months; Fluenz (AstraZeneca) nasal spray for children and adolescents 2‑18; Influvac S and Influvac S Tetra (Viatris) for adults and children ≥ 6 months; Vaxigrip and Vaxigrip Tetra (Sanofi Winthrop) for adults, including pregnant women, and children ≥ 6 months. The Ministry of Health recommends that regional campaigns start in early October and that vaccination be offered freely to all eligible persons, including those 60 years and older, pregnant women, children 6 months‑6 years, individuals with chronic diseases, residents of long‑term care facilities, close contacts of high‑risk patients, and public‑service workers such as doctors, nurses, police and firefighters. AIFA notes that vaccine safety is monitored through the National Pharmacovigilance Network (RNF) and Regional Pharmacovigilance Centres (CRFV), with data shared with EMA for coordinated European monitoring. The agency also stresses that good hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette remain key measures to limit influenza spread. The article states that 'I vaccini antinfluenzali sono utilizzati da anni nelle campagne vaccinali ed hanno un profilo di sicurezza consolidato.' and that 'Il Ministero della Salute ha raccomandato di 'condurre le campagne di vaccinazione antinfluenzale regionali a partire dall'inizio di ottobre...'.

**Public Flu Vaccine Rollout on Oct 1; CDC Switches to Trivalent Vaccine for This Year**
The Taiwan Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced that the public‑funded influenza vaccination campaign will begin on 1 October.  In a shift from the previous four‑valent formulation, the CDC will procure a trivalent vaccine for the 2024 season.  The change follows a World Health Organization (WHO) recommendation that, since March 2020, no natural B‑type Yamagata strain has been detected worldwide, and that the strain should be removed from vaccine compositions.  CDC Deputy Director Tseng Shih‑hui explained that the decision was made after the 24 January 2024 advisory meeting of the Ministry of Health and Welfare’s Infectious Disease Prevention and Control Advisory Committee.  The agency will purchase 6 864 910 trivalent doses, of which 6 479 080 are earmarked for the 114‑year influenza vaccination program, 185 830 for central and local procurement, and an additional 200 000 doses may be ordered to meet demand.  The procurement cost is about 1.57 billion New Taiwan dollars.  Five manufacturers—Guangong, GlaxoSmithKline, Taiwan Oriental, Sanofi, and High‑End Vaccine—will supply the vaccine.  Children from elementary to high school, vocational, and junior college first‑through‑third‑year students will receive the vaccine on campus to reduce travel for parents.  The CDC is also improving the “Vaccination Administration Electronic System (NIAS)” so parents can sign consent online via a QR code or link, or use paper forms if preferred.  Tseng noted that the switch to a trivalent vaccine aligns Taiwan with advanced countries and follows WHO guidance.

**VACCINE CULTISTS at the CDC and FDA are being ousted right and left as Trump and RFK Jr. clean house and drain the PHARMA SWAMP   - NaturalNews.com**
The article reports a dramatic shift in U.S. public‑health policy, noting that former President Donald Trump has publicly distanced himself from the COVID‑19 vaccines produced under his Operation Warp Speed, and that HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has taken aggressive steps to overhaul the CDC and FDA. In a Senate Finance Committee hearing, Kennedy was questioned by Senator Ron Wyden about alleged statements to former CDC Director Susan Monarrez; Kennedy denied the claim, saying, 'No, I did not say that to her,' and later replied, 'Yes, sir,' when Wyden asked if Monarrez was lying. The hearing highlighted a growing political rift over vaccine mandates and pharmaceutical influence. Simultaneously, Dr. Paul Offit, a long‑time FDA vaccine advisor and co‑inventor of Merck’s RotaTeq, was abruptly removed from the FDA’s Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee (VRBPAC) with no explanation. Offit’s career has been marked by controversy over his financial ties to Merck and his outspoken defense of universal immunization, including the claim that infants could safely receive '10,000 vaccines at once.' The article frames these events as a collapse of a ‘public health house of cards,’ suggesting a seismic shift that may lead to greater transparency or deeper political polarization. The piece is sourced from NaturalNews.com and published on September 5 2025.

**NY Gov. Hochul jabs RFK Jr. with order making COVID vaccine available...**
Gov. Kathy Hochul signed an executive order on Friday to expand COVID‑19 vaccine access in New York, allowing pharmacists to prescribe and administer shots, including boosters for children as young as three. The order, which will remain in effect for at least 30 days while a long‑term legislative solution is developed, is framed as a response to what the governor calls the ‘Trump Administration’s misguided attack on immunization and healthcare’ and to the federal Health and Human Services (HHS) secretary’s decision in May to stop recommending COVID vaccines for healthy children and pregnant women. Hochul’s office said the order will ‘ensure that all eligible New Yorkers – including children, pregnant people, and healthy adults under 65 – can continue to receive COVID vaccinations at their local pharmacy without delay.’ The state health commissioner, Dr. James McDonald, will issue a standing order to support the pharmacists’ authority. The move follows a tense Senate Finance Committee hearing in which Sen. Bill Cassidy criticized HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for allegedly refusing COVID vaccines to those who need them; Kennedy denied this, stating that anyone can get a free vaccine at a pharmacy but that some are being selective due to unclear federal regulations. The article cites the FDA’s approval of the updated shot only for older and high‑risk Americans and notes that the CDC’s advisory panel will not meet until September 18 to develop broader guidance.

**RFK Jr Doesn't Care About Long COVID**
During his confirmation hearings, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. pledged to prioritize Long COVID, promising to fund research and diagnostics. By August 2025, he had dismantled key federal programs: the Office of Long COVID Research and Practice was closed, the National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion was consolidated, and NIH‑funded clinical trials for antivirals and immunotherapies were halted. The cuts also stopped large‑scale cohort studies and diagnostics development. Kennedy’s reorganization coincided with a Trump executive order to reduce federal bureaucracy, but the agency’s actions alone bear responsibility. He has also restricted COVID‑vaccination access: the FDA denied approval for vaccines under 65 without high‑risk conditions, revoked EUA for Pfizer’s vaccine in children under 5, and limited Moderna’s formulation to high‑risk children. The CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices was overhauled, replacing members with vaccine skeptics. Kennedy cut $500 million from mRNA research, halted CastleVax’s intranasal vaccine, and altered wastewater surveillance thresholds, reducing data reliability. These moves undermine prevention, research, and public health infrastructure, leaving millions of Long COVID patients without support. The article argues that Kennedy’s policies reflect an ableist, anti‑vaccine agenda that prioritizes political ideology over science and public health.

Key metrics: a meta‑analysis shows vaccination reduces Long COVID risk by ~30 %; 5.8 million U.S. children are affected by post‑COVID conditions; Kennedy’s cuts eliminated $500 million in mRNA research.

Quotes: Kennedy said, 'Absolutely, senator, with enthusiasm.'

**Holland & Knight Health Dose: September 3, 2025**
U.S. Congress has reconvened after its August recess for a brief session, facing a looming to‑do list to extend government funding beyond Sept. 30, 2025. The current continuing resolution (CR) expires on Sept. 30, leaving about 28 days to negotiate an extension—likely into December 2025—while a shutdown remains the most probable outcome. The House Appropriations Committee will consider additional appropriations bills in September, including the Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies Bill, which is "often one of - if not the most - controversial spending bills considered," due to the many policy riders it carries. HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is scheduled to testify before the Senate Finance Committee on Sept. 4, 2025, on the CDC leadership changes, while Deputy Secretary Jim O’Neill will serve as acting CDC director. The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health will hold a hearing on Sept. 3 on AI in health care, and the Senate Special Committee on Aging will hold a hearing on Sept. 3 on protecting older workers. The Senate Finance Committee will consider nominations on Sept. 4 for HHS positions. Key deadlines include Sept. 12 for MPFS CY 2026 proposed‑rule comments, Sept. 15 for OPPS CY 2026 comments, Sept. 29 for drugmakers to meet the MFN pricing mandate, and Sept. 30 for the government‑funding deadline. The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) meeting on Sept. 18‑19 is postponed indefinitely by HELP Chair Bill Cassidy, citing "the move raised some bipartisan concern." Holland & Knight will host its second annual Hospital Horizons Symposium on Oct. 6‑7. Executive‑order activity: the Trump administration rescinded nearly $5 billion in foreign aid on Aug. 29, raising concerns under the Impoundment Control Act; Senate Appropriations Chair Susan Collins called the action illegal. The Rural Health Transformation Program (RHTP) launched a website on Sept. 3, with applications to be released mid‑September. The FDA revoked all remaining EUAs for COVID‑19 vaccines on Aug. 27, limiting access to authorized vaccines for high‑risk groups. MedPAC will hold a public meeting on Sept. 4‑5, and MACPAC will meet on Sept. 18‑19. NIH issued policy NOT‑OD‑25‑132 on July 31 to curb AI‑generated grant applications. CMS announced a fraud competition using explainable AI. The CDC’s ACIP is preparing for a Sept. 18‑19 meeting amid internal upheaval.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 04, 2025 09:05 PM
Source:[JD Supra](https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/holland-knight-health-dose-september-3-2437098/)

**Fall vaccine season: sorting through the confusion**
The article explains the fall vaccination schedule, highlighting the three main vaccines—flu, RSV, and Covid—along with age‑specific recommendations and key dates. For the flu, it states that everyone six months and older should be vaccinated by the end of October; children 6 months to 8 years need two doses four weeks apart if it is their first shot; adults 65+ should receive a high‑dose, recombinant, or adjuvanted vaccine, while those 18‑64 who have had a solid‑organ transplant are also advised to use a stronger formulation. The RSV section notes a one‑time vaccine for adults 75+ and for adults 50‑74 with chronic conditions, listing the available options—Abrysvo, Arexvy, and mResvia—as equally recommended. Pregnant women at 32‑36 weeks should receive Abrysvo between September and January to protect their newborns, who can alternatively receive a monoclonal antibody injection after birth. The Covid section reports that the FDA has approved an updated 2025‑2026 vaccine for adults 65+ and for people 6 months and older with underlying health conditions; the CDC advisory panel will meet on September 18‑19 to decide on broader recommendations, and if a narrower group is chosen, other eligible individuals may still receive the vaccine "off‑label". The article emphasizes focusing on age, health conditions, and risk level each fall to protect oneself and the community.

**Everything you need to know about getting COVID, flu vaccines in Colorado this fall - Real Vail**
The article explains that the 2025‑26 COVID‑19 and flu vaccines are now available and are designed to protect against the latest respiratory virus variants. It notes that the updated COVID‑19 shots target the newest variants, while flu vaccines are updated annually to match the most likely strains for the upcoming season. The piece highlights recent federal uncertainty: the CDC director was fired, and the FDA has imposed new restrictions that could limit vaccine access and create cost‑related barriers. Insurance coverage for the shots is unclear, with some plans potentially requiring co‑pays. The author, Dr. Barron, urges readers to ignore misinformation and to get vaccinated, citing that “Updated flu and COVID‑19 vaccines reduce severe illness, hospitalizations and deaths from respiratory viruses.” She emphasizes that high‑risk groups—older adults, people with asthma, COPD, hematologic malignancies, immunocompromised patients, pregnant women, and health‑care workers—should prioritize vaccination. Dr. Barron also explains that vaccines do not guarantee immunity but significantly lower the risk of severe disease and enable people to continue daily activities. She advises consulting a doctor for a prescription if needed, as some pharmacies now require one for COVID‑19 shots. The article concludes that the best time to get vaccinated is when it is convenient, because protection lasts for months and the flu season typically runs from October through May.

**Flu season approaches**
Globe Gazette reports that the 2025‑26 flu season will still rely on the annual flu shot as the main preventive measure. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) continues to recommend that all people aged six months and older receive a yearly flu vaccine, and most insurers will cover it. Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has previously opposed vaccines, nevertheless agreed that most people should get the flu shot. A federal panel rejected a recommendation for multidose shots containing thimerosal, but the preservative has already been removed from most flu vaccines. The vaccine for this season is a trivalent formulation that protects against two influenza A strains and one influenza B strain, with an updated A/H3N2 component that aligns with WHO guidance. Experts advise getting vaccinated in September, October, or early November so that antibody levels peak before the February influenza peak. While the vaccine does not guarantee perfect protection, it reduces the risk of severe illness and death; as William Schaffner, a Vanderbilt professor, said, 'protecting us from the most severe consequences of influenza.' Benjamin Lee, a pediatric infectious diseases physician, added, 'A flu vaccine may not guarantee perfect protection against the flu, but skipping your flu shot simply guarantees you'll have no protection at all.' The FDA approved the vaccine formula on March 13, and manufacturers are expected to have an adequate supply by September. Funding cuts announced by Kennedy—$500 million for mRNA vaccine development—have raised uncertainty about future vaccine innovation, though no mRNA flu vaccines are currently approved.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 01, 2025 07:39 PM
Source:[Globe Gazette](https://globegazette.com/article_1598021b-1a07-42e7-b741-1279a52710df.html)

**Prevention and Control of Seasonal Influenza...**
CDC’s 2025‑26 influenza vaccine recommendations specify that all U.S. vaccines will be trivalent, containing the following strains: an H1N1pdm09‑like virus derived from A/Victoria/4897/2022 (egg‑based) or A/Wisconsin/67/2022 (cell‑culture or recombinant); an H3N2‑like virus derived from A/Croatia/10136RV/2023 (egg‑based) or A/District of Columbia/27/2023 (cell‑culture or recombinant); and an influenza B Victoria‑lineage virus derived from B/Austria/1359417/2021. This updates the H3N2 component from the 2024‑25 season. Routine annual vaccination is recommended for all persons ≥6 months without contraindication. The CDC advises that most people receive one dose in September or October, but vaccination can continue after October as long as viruses circulate and vaccine is available. "Vaccination during July and August is not recommended for most groups because of potential waning of vaccine‑induced immunity during the influenza season." **COVID-19 Vaccines for Use in the United States Beginning in Fall 2025**
The FDA's Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee (VRBPAC) met on May 22, 2025, to discuss and recommend COVID-19 vaccine compositions for use in the United States beginning in fall 2025. The committee unanimously voted to recommend a monovalent JN.1-lineage vaccine composition, with a preference for the LP.8.1 strain. This decision was based on the totality of evidence, including manufacturing timelines, SARS-CoV-2 virus variant circulation, current vaccine effectiveness, and human immunogenicity data. FDA has advised manufacturers to produce monovalent JN.1-lineage-based COVID-19 vaccines (2025-2026 Formula) to match currently circulating SARS-CoV-2 viruses.
